herbs.name: Ashwagandha
herbs.description: Ashwagandha, scientifically known as Withania somnifera, is an adaptogenic herb that is often referred to as 'Indian ginseng.' It is highly regarded in Ayurvedic medicine for its stress-relieving properties. Ashwagandha helps the body adapt to stress, reducing cortisol levels and promoting a sense of calm. It is also known for its ability to boost energy, enhance cognitive function, and improve overall vitality.

herbs.name: Turmeric
herbs.description: Turmeric, a bright yellow spice derived from the root of Curcuma longa, is renowned for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. The active compound in turmeric, curcumin, has been extensively studied for its health benefits. In Ayurveda, turmeric is used to promote joint health, reduce pain and inflammation, support digestion, and enhance overall well-being.

herbs.name: Neem
herbs.description: Neem, or Azadirachta indica, is a versatile herb known for its potent anti-bacterial, anti-fungal, and anti-inflammatory properties. Neem has a long history of use in Ayurvedic medicine for various skin conditions, such as acne and eczema. It is also used for oral health, promoting healthy gums and freshening the breath.

herbs.name: Tulsi (Holy Basil)
herbs.description: Tulsi, also known as Holy Basil or Ocimum sanctum, is revered in Ayurveda for its immunity-boosting and anti-inflammatory qualities. This aromatic herb is known for reducing stress, enhancing respiratory health, and promoting mental clarity. Tulsi is often consumed as a tea to harness its many therapeutic benefits.

herbs.name: Amla (Indian Gooseberry)
herbs.description: Amla, scientifically known as Phyllanthus emblica, is a fruit rich in vitamin C and is often referred to as the 'Indian Gooseberry.' It is prized in Ayurveda for its rejuvenating and anti-aging properties. Amla supports the immune system, promotes healthy hair and skin, and helps in maintaining overall vitality and well-being.

herbs.name: Ginger
herbs.description: Ginger, or Zingiber officinale, is a warming herb with a long history of use in Ayurvedic and traditional medicine. It is well-known for its digestive benefits, aiding in the relief of nausea, indigestion, and bloating. Additionally, ginger possesses anti-inflammatory properties, making it a versatile herb for overall well-being.

herbs.name: Brahmi
herbs.description: Brahmi, scientifically known as Bacopa monnieri, is a renowned Ayurvedic herb known for its cognitive-enhancing properties. It supports memory and mental clarity, making it a valuable herb for improving focus, learning, and overall brain function. Brahmi is often used in herbal preparations to enhance mental agility.

herbs.name: Haritaki
herbs.description: Haritaki, or Terminalia chebula, is a powerful Ayurvedic herb known for its digestive benefits. It aids in improving bowel regularity and detoxifying the body. Haritaki is also recognized for its mild laxative properties, which promote healthy digestion and the elimination of waste products.

herbs.name: Guggul
herbs.description: Guggul, derived from the resin of the Commiphora wightii tree, is used in Ayurveda for its cholesterol-lowering and anti-inflammatory effects. It is particularly valuable for supporting joint health and promoting overall well-being. Guggul is often included in formulations aimed at managing lipid levels and supporting healthy joints.

herbs.name: Shatavari
herbs.description: Shatavari, scientifically known as Asparagus racemosus, is a key herb in women's health in Ayurveda. It is renowned for its hormone-balancing and rejuvenating properties. Shatavari supports female reproductive health, eases menstrual discomfort, and promotes vitality and well-being. It is often used to maintain hormonal balance.

herbs.name: Triphala
herbs.description: Triphala is a combination of three fruits: Amalaki, Bibhitaki, and Haritaki. It is often used as a gentle detoxifier and digestive aid in Ayurveda. Triphala supports healthy digestion, regular bowel movements, and overall gastrointestinal health. It is known for its ability to cleanse and rejuvenate the digestive system.

herbs.name: Bhringraj
herbs.description: Bhringraj, scientifically known as Eclipta alba, is a herb used in Ayurveda for its hair-nourishing properties. It promotes hair growth, reduces hair fall, and supports overall hair health. Bhringraj is often used in herbal hair oils and hair care formulations.

herbs.name: Manjistha
herbs.description: Manjistha, or Rubia cordifolia, is a blood-purifying herb used in Ayurveda to support skin health and overall detoxification. It aids in removing toxins from the blood and promotes clear, radiant skin. Manjistha is often recommended for individuals with skin conditions or those seeking to enhance their complexion.

herbs.name: Arjuna
herbs.description: Arjuna, or Terminalia arjuna, is an Ayurvedic herb known for its benefits to heart health. It is used to support cardiovascular function, improve heart muscle strength, and maintain healthy blood pressure levels. Arjuna has been traditionally used to promote overall cardiovascular well-being.

herbs.name: Punarnava
herbs.description: Punarnava, or Boerhavia diffusa, is a diuretic herb used in Ayurveda for kidney and urinary tract health. It helps flush out excess fluids, supports kidney function, and promotes urinary system well-being. Punarnava is often recommended for maintaining fluid balance in the body.

herbs.name: Kutki
herbs.description: Kutki, scientifically known as Picrorhiza kurroa, is used in Ayurveda for liver detoxification and to support liver health. It is recognized for its ability to improve liver function, protect against liver damage, and promote overall liver well-being. Kutki is often included in herbal formulations aimed at liver support.

herbs.name: Amalaki
herbs.description: Amalaki, or Emblica officinalis, is another name for the Indian Gooseberry, similar to Amla. It is rich in vitamin C and is used in Ayurveda for its immune-boosting and rejuvenating properties. Amalaki supports the immune system, promotes healthy skin and hair, and helps in maintaining overall vitality and well-being.

herbs.name: Vidanga
herbs.description: Vidanga, scientifically known as Embelia ribes, is used in Ayurveda for digestive health and as an anti-parasitic herb. It aids in improving digestion, reducing intestinal parasites, and supporting gastrointestinal well-being. Vidanga is often included in herbal formulations to address digestive concerns.

herbs.name: Mulethi (Licorice)
herbs.description: Mulethi, also known as Licorice or Glycyrrhiza glabra, is known for its soothing properties in Ayurveda. It is used to alleviate respiratory discomfort, soothe coughs and sore throats, and support digestive health. Mulethi is often included in herbal remedies to provide relief from various respiratory and digestive issues.

herbs.name: Pippali (Long Pepper)
herbs.description: Pippali, scientifically known as Piper longum, is used in Ayurveda for digestive support, respiratory health, and as a bioavailability enhancer. It aids in digestion, enhances the absorption of nutrients, and supports the respiratory system. Pippali is often combined with other herbs to enhance their effectiveness.
